_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. We at Taft Manufacturing Company Acrolein Plant are strongly committed to protection of human health and the environment.  This committment is inherent to our comprehensive accidental release prevention program in place that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training.  It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  If such a release does occur, our emergency repsonse personnel are at hand to control and mitigate the effects of the release.

2. Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled

Our facility's primary activities encompass manufacture and transfer of Acrolein, a chemical used in oilfield and agricultural applications from bulk containers into transfer and shipping / dispenser containers, with attendant rework and service of the containers.

Acrolein is used as a pesticide.

A raw material used in the acrolein manufacturing process is propylene.  Propylene is to be received in railcars for use in the chemical process.

3. Worst Case Release Scenarios and the Alternative Release Scenarios, including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario are as follows:


Worst Case Scenario for Acrolein 

The Worst Case Scenario submitted for toxic substances involves a catastrophic release of acrolein.  We have used the look-up tables and equations provided by the U.S. EPA in the Risk Management Program Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA).  The scenario involves the release of 35,000 lbs of acrolein (from an ISO container) as a liquid spill / vapor release over 10 minutes.  Passive mitigation controls such as dikes were not used, as this feature would be ineffective for gas release.  At Class "F" atmospheric stability and 1.5 meters / sec windspeed, with urban topography, the distance to the toxic endpoint of 0.011 mg/L is 25 miles according to Reference Table 7 of the OCA Gui

dance Document.


Alternate Case Scenario for Acrolein

One Alternative Release Scenario for acrolein involves release from a skid unprotected by a deluge system arising from puncture of the skid by the blade or a forklift.  The alternative release scenario for acrolein was prepared based on the Safer System Trace Model.  The scenario involves the release of 2,450 pounds at the rate of 40.8 pounds per minute over a time period of 60 minutes.  (The maximum net weight of a skid is 2,450 pounds, but allowance is made for fluctuation in actual contents, polymerization of contents upon release to an ambient atmosphere, etc.).  Passive mitigation controls such as dikes were not used as such controls would not apply to a vapor release.  At "D" atmospheric stability and 3.0 meters /sec windspeed, with urban topography, the projected distance to the toxic endpoint of 0.011 mg/L is 6.3 miles.   

Worst Case Scenario for Propylene

The Worst Case Scenario submitted for flammable substances involves the catastrophic release of propylene.  We have used the computer model RMP Comp Ver. 1.07. provided by the U.S. EPA.  The scenario involves the release of 40,000 gallons or 173,600 lbs of propylene as a vapor cloud.    Passive mitigation controls such as dikes were not used, as this feature would be ineffective for vapor release.  At Class "F" atmospheric stability and 1.5 meters / sec windspeed, with urban topography, the distance to the endpoint of 1 psi overpressure is 0.4 miles according to RMP Comp.

Alternate Case Scenario for Propylene

The Alternative Release Scenario submitted for flammable substances involves the catastrophic release of propylene.  We have used the computer model RMP Comp Ver. 1.07. provided by the U.S. EPA.  The scenario involves the release of 1,244 lbs/hr (the propylene feed rate at 10 million pound per year of acrolein production) of propylene as a vapor cloud.    Passive mitigation controls such as dikes were not used, as this feature would be ineffe

ctive for gas release.  At Class "D" atmospheric stability and 3 meters / sec windspeed, with urban topography, the distance to the endpoint of 1 psi overpressure is less than 0.1 miles according to RMP Comp.

4. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Our facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR 68 by U.S. EPA as well as the requirements of the California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Public Safety, Div. 2, Office of Emergency Services, Chapter 4.5 California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.   A number of process at our facility are subject to the OSHA PSM standard under 29 CFR 1910.119.  Our facility is also subject to EPCRA Section 302 notification requirements.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at our stationary source.

Process Safety Information - Taft Manufacturing Company maintains a detailed record of safety information that describes chemical hazards, operating parameters, and equipment designs associated with all processes.

Process Hazard Analyses - Our facility conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled efficiently.  The methodology used to carry out these analyses is the HAZOP method.  The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with experience in engineering, plant operations, and/or maintenance.   Employees get to make suggestions to improve the environmental operation of their work environment.  The analyses are reviewed and revalidated at least every five years.  Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

Operating Procedures - For the purposes of safely conducting within our covered processes, Taft Manufacturing Company maintains written operating procedures.   These procedures address normal operations, includin

g start-up, shutdown, and emergency operations.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.

Training - Taft Manufacturing Company has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.

Mechanical Integrity - Taft Manufacturing Company carries out well documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps.  Taft Manufacturing Company also participates in a quarterly leak detection and repair program.   Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with training in maintenance practices.  Furthermore, these personnel are provided specialized training as needed.   Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

Management of Change - Written procedures are in place at Taft Manufacturing Company to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and provided training to deal with the modification.

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews - Pre-startup safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted as a regular practice at this Taft Manufacturing Company site.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating, and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment in operation.  There have been significant changes to the equipment at Taft Manufacturing Company.  An overview of the new chemical process is as follows:

Air, proylene and stea

m will be used to produce specification-grade acrolein.  The raw materials are fed to a reactor with a catalyst that converts proylene to acrolein.  The outlet stream consists of acrolein, unreacted propylene and oxygen, nitrogen, steam, and small amounts of by-products.  The acrolein is separated from the other materials in the stream through a series of two quench columns, a stripper, and two distillation columns.   The final product is to be stored in each of three 1,000 gallon vessels.  This product will ultimately be transfered to the acrolein repackaging plant. 

A 16.3 MM Btu / hr thermal oxidizer is used to control emissions associated with the facility's process vents and polymerized streams.   Nearly 80% of the facility's steam requirements are produced in an unfired heat recovery steam generator that recovers heat from the facility's thermal oxidizer.   Recovering heat generated by the acrolein production reaction produces the remainder of the steam required.         

Off-site and utility systems to support the process plant include propylene storage in railcars, reaction inhibitor makeup and storage, water systems, cooling water, chilled water system, instrument air, emergency power, and an emergency flare system.

Compliance Audits - Taft Manufacturing Company conducts internal audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented.  These audits of RMP covered processes are conducted at least every three years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are initiated in a prompt manner.

Incident Investigation - Taft Manufacturing Company promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could have reasonably resulted in, a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reocurring.  All reports are maintained for a minimum of 5

years.

Employee Participation - Taft Manufacturing Company believes that process safety management and accident prevention requires a team effort.  Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and recommend improvements.  In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses.

Contractors - On occasion, our company hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out.  Taft Manufacturing Company has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the processes.   Contractors are informed of all of the procedures for emergency response in the event that an accidental release of a substance occurs.  Concurrently, contractors are required to provide full information including MSDS for any hazardous chemicals, processes, or procedures they use to which our employees may be exposed.

An independent contractor, Insight Environmental, conducts quarterly monitoring of all site piping, couplings, and valves.  All piping and transfer systems were constructed in compliance with state and federal codes and are so maintained.  The existing facility was constructed in 1985 and the new faclity was constructed in 2002-2003 in compliance with the Uniform Building Code for Kern County.  All related permits and inspection documentation is on file with the Kern County Building Permitting Dept.

5.  Five-Year Accident History

Taft Manufacturing Company Acrolein Plant (formerly Baker-Petrolite) has had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last five years.  Due to our stringent release prevention policies, there have been no federal or state reportable accidental releases of RMP

regulated substances over this period.

6. Emergency Response Plan

The Taft Manufacturing Company Acrolein Plant maintains a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of all affected areas.

The plant has recently installed acrolein detectors around the perimeter of the plant, at the new acrolein product storage tanks, and at the base of the process area to measure ambient acrolein.  Additionally, lower explosive limit detectors are installed around the thermal oxidizer, reactor, and around the propylene railcar staging area.  The data from the detectors is sent to the continually-occupied control room where the operator is notified of alarm conditions.   Also, an automatic foam deluge system will be activated at the acrolein product storage tanks, to apply alchohol fire fighting foam (AFFF) in the containment area.   An automatic water deluge sytsem will be activated at the proylene storage area, to apply water to the propylene railcars.  Additionally, fire monitors can be used to apply water or AFFF to any part of the process area.

7. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

As a result of loss control audits, excess flow prevention controls were installed on each of the two unloading platforms for our bulk acrolein unloading stations.
